titleStmt.title: Register for Amphikrates the tripod carrier in the fourth Pythais

div.p:
For the Good Fortune of the Council and the People of the Athenians.
In the archonship of Mentor at Delphi and in Athens
of Argeios (97/6), (he who) took the sacred tripod from Delphi and
carried it away, and led the fire-bearer (is) Amphikrates
son of Epistratos, Athenian.

!+1+ This text, inscribed on the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury, is likely to serve as the preamble of an honorific decree. It was engraved right below the list of magistrates organising the fourth Pythais in 97/6 BC (F.Delphes III 2, 6) and near the other lists of participants in this Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 2, 6, 10, 16, 17, 26, 31, 45). On the Pythais and the Treasury, see F.Delphes III 2, 3, on Attic inscriptions at Delphi, see IG II3 4, 17 with notes, and on the fourth Pythais . After the procession arrived at Delphi, the Athenian participants acquired the sacred fire and tripod there. A man and a woman were appointed to take charge in carrying the tripod and the fire, respectively, back to Athens. Sources about this ritual include F.Delphes III 2, 33 (bearer of the tripod in the second Pythais, 128/7 BC), F.Delphes III 2, 13, ll. 1–2 (Pyrphoros in the third Pythais, 106/5 BC). On this ritual, see S. Kühn, Pythaïs-Prozession, 128–130. On the role of the tripod in Athenian narrative about Delphi, see also Pöhlmann and West, Greek Music no. 20, l. 21 and Pöhlmann and West, Greek Music no. 21, l. 22. Amphikrates participated in the third Pythais in 106/5 BC as the sacrificer of the first fruits (epi tas aparchas, F.Delphes III 2, 13, l. 20) and ordered to inscribe the benefactors for the first fruits in the fourth Pythais (IG II2 2336 + SEG 32.218, ll. 1-4).!
